questions.text: Based on the features observed in the diagram, which of the following organisms does this life cycle most likely belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba histolytica

 

  • The life cycle depicted in the image shows stages that include trophozoites, which are active feeding stages, and cysts, which are the infective stages passed in feces.
  • Entamoeba histolytica, the causative agent of amoebiasis, follows this life cycle.
  • It forms cysts that are capable of surviving outside the host in harsh conditions and trophozoites that cause disease within the host's intestine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Balantidium coli: Balantidium coli, though it forms cysts and trophozoites, the morphology shown in the image does not match its typical appearance which generally shows a more distinct ciliary pattern.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm and does not have a cyst stage; its life cycle involves larval stages in the environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, or pinworm, has a life cycle that includes eggs and adult worms, but does not form cysts or trophozoites like those depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Life cycle of E. histolytica -
  • Ingestion of quadri-nucleated cyst → develops to trophozoites →multiply in large intestine → develops to precyst → cyst (immature) → quadri-nucleated cyst (mature) passes in stool.

choices.text: Superficial palmar branch of median nerve
Recurrent branch of median nerve
Deep branch of ulnar nerve

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy tripped while running in a playground, sustained lacerations at the base of his thumb from a broken glass bottle. Examination revealed that he could not oppose his thumb to his fingers, and there was weakness in thumb abduction and flexion. No sensory deficits were noted. Which nerve was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent branch of median nerve

 

  • This branch of the median nerve is specifically responsible for motor control of the thenar muscles, which facilitate thumb opposition, abduction, and flexion.
  • The clinical symptoms of inability to oppose the thumb, coupled with weakness in abduction and flexion, directly correlate with an injury to this nerve.
  • The absence of sensory deficits aligns with the recurrent branch's predominantly motor function.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial palmar branch of median nerve: This nerve primarily provides sensory innervation to the palm of the hand and does not influence motor functions, making it less likely to be involved given the motor deficits described.

 

Option C. Deep branch of ulnar nerve: This nerve affects the ulnar side of the hand, influencing the intrinsic muscles but not primarily responsible for thumb movements, which are crucially controlled by the median nerve.

 

Option D. Radial nerve: Typically, responsible for wrist and finger extension. While it also innervates some muscles involved in thumb abduction (such as the extensor pollicis longus and brevis), its primary functions do not include opposition or the specific type of flexion described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recurrent branch of the median nerve is critical for thumb movements including opposition, abduction, and flexion.
  • Injury to this nerve results in characteristic deficits of these thumb functions without affecting sensation, highlighting its importance in thumb motor control.

questions.text: In a routine screening for intestinal parasites at a rural clinic near Pune, a medical technician uses a saturated salt solution floatation method to analyze stool samples. This technique is utilized to detect various helminthic eggs by exploiting differences in their buoyancy. One particular type of egg, however, is known not to float in this solution due to its higher density. Which of the following helminthic eggs is least likely to float in a saturated salt solution?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eggs of Taenia solium

 

  • The eggs of Taenia solium, known as the pork tapeworm, typically do not float in a saturated salt solution used in stool sample analysis.
  • This is due to their higher specific gravity, which keeps them from rising in the solution, unlike the lighter eggs of other helminths that are typically detected using this method.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eggs of Necator americanus: Eggs of Necator americanus are lighter and generally float in the saturated salt solution, facilitating their detection.

 

Option B. Eggs of Enterobius vermicularis: Eggs of Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm eggs, are also light enough to float, making them easily identifiable in such flotation methods.

 

Option C. Eggs of Hymenolepis nana: Eggs of Hymenolepis nana, despite being from the tapeworm family, are light enough to generally float in a saturated salt solution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eggs of all the following helminthic worms float in a saturated salt solution EXCEPT -
  • ULTO- Unfertilized eggs of Ascaris, Larva of Strongyloides, Taenia eggs and Operculated eggs of trematodes

choices.text: Tidal volume should be set at 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight (IBW).
Respiratory rate should be initially set at 12-16 breaths per minute.
Initial FiO2 should be set at 100% and reduced as tolerated to avoid oxygen toxicity.
PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted.

questions.text: A patient suffering from acute respiratory distress following CABG for coronary artery disease is being prepared for mechanical ventilation. Which of the following statements about lung protective ventilatory settings is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PEEP should be set at 5 cm H2O and not adjusted

 

  • Not True. PEEP is initially set at 5 cm H2O to prevent alveolar collapse at end expiration.
  • However, in the setting of cardiac surgery and concerns about impairing ventricular filling, careful titration of PEEP above the initial setting is advised to optimize oxygenation and ventilation without compromising hemodynamics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tidal volume should be set at 4-6 ml/kg of ideal body weight (IBW): True. The recommended initial tidal volume for mechanical ventilation is 4-6 ml/kg based on the patient’s ideal body weight to prevent barotrauma and volutrauma.

 

Option B. Respiratory rate should be initially set at 12-16 breaths per minute: True. A respiratory rate of 12 to 16 breaths per minute is a common initial setting which can be adjusted based on the patient's gas exchange and acid-base status.

 

Option C. Initial FiO2 should be set at 100% and reduced as tolerated to avoid oxygen toxicity: True. Starting with an FiO2 of 100% is a typical approach in critically ill patients to ensure adequate oxygenation. The FiO2 is usually titrated down to avoid oxygen toxicity, depending on arterial blood gases and oxygen saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When initiating mechanical ventilation, it is critical to start with safe settings tailored to the patient’s lung mechanics and underlying pathology.
  • The initial PEEP setting should be low but requires careful adjustment, to balance lung recruitment and cardiac output.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman in her first pregnancy is at her 8-week prenatal visit. She expresses concern about the risk of Down syndrome, noting her understanding that increased maternal age can elevate risk. Which of the following prenatal screening tests should be recommended to this patient for the highest detection rate of Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell-free DNA

 

  • This test analyzes fetal DNA found in the mother's blood and is known for its high detection rate for chromosomal abnormalities, including Down syndrome.
  • It is especially recommended for women of advanced maternal age due to its high sensitivity and low false-positive rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated test: This combines data from the first trimester screening (nuchal translucency, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A) and second trimester screening (hCG, estriol, inhibin-A, and AFP) for a cumulative risk assessment. While comprehensive, it does not match the detection rate of cell-free DNA.

 

Option C. Quadruple test: Conducted in the second trimester, this screens levels of four substances in the mother's blood. It has a lower detection rate compared to cell-free DNA.

 

Option D. Amniocentesis: While offering definitive genetic testing, this is an invasive diagnostic procedure rather than a screening test and carries a risk of miscarriage. It is typically reserved for cases where high-risk results are obtained from non-invasive screening tests or there are other indications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a woman of advanced maternal age seeking the screening test with the highest detection rate for Down syndrome, cell-free DNA screening is the most effective and least invasive option currently available, making it the recommended choice.

choices.text: 0.75, suggesting the program was effective in reducing mortality
1.33, suggesting the program increased mortality
1.00, suggesting the program had no effect on mortality
0.50, suggesting a significant reduction in mortality

questions.text:
Dr. Iyer is conducting a study to assess the effectiveness of a new diabetes management program in a suburban area of India. She collects mortality data for patients with diabetes both before and after the implementation of the program. To ensure the validity of her comparisons given the different age structures of the populations at different times, she decides to use an epidemiological tool that adjusts mortality rates to a standard age distribution. The following data is provided:

 

  • Observed deaths in the suburban area post-program implementation: 120
  • Expected deaths based on a standard age distribution, had the program not been implemented: 160

 

Calculate the Standardized Mortality Ratio (SMR) for the suburban area following the program implementation and determine what it suggests about the effectiveness of the program.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.75, suggesting the program was effective in reducing mortality

 

The Standardized Mortality Ratio (SMR) is calculated as follows:

 

SMR = Observed Deaths/ Expected Deaths = 120/ 160 = 0.75

 

An SMR of 0.75 indicates that the observed number of deaths was 25% lower than expected if the program had not been implemented. This result suggests that the diabetes management program was effective in reducing mortality among patients with diabetes in the suburban area.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form
  • Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population.

questions.text: A physician suspects a patient has impaired bile pigment excretion due to liver dysfunction. Which of the following tests should be employed to assess the presence of bile salts in the patient's urine?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Hay's test

 

  • Hay's test is specifically designed to detect the presence of bile salts in the urine.
  • This test is employed when a physician suspects liver dysfunction impacting bile pigment excretion. Hay's test is conducted by sprinkling sulfur powder over a urine sample.
  • If bile salts are present, the sulfur powder will sink due to the reduction in surface tension of the urine, which is directly affected by the presence of bile salts.
  • This simple yet effective diagnostic method helps in assessing liver function regarding bile salt handling.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rothera's test: This test is utilized to detect the presence of ketone bodies in urine, which is typically associated with diabetic ketoacidosis or other conditions causing significant metabolic disturbances. It is not used for detecting bile salts or assessing liver function related to bile pigment excretion.

 

 

Option C. Ehrlich's test: Ehrlich's test is used primarily to detect the presence of urobilinogen in the urine. While urobilinogen is related to bile metabolism, it is not a direct measure of bile salts and does not provide specific information about bile salt excretion impairments.

 

 

Option D. Fouchet's test: Fouchet's test is used for the detection of bilirubin in the urine or serum. Although bilirubin is a bile pigment, the test does not assess bile salts, which are a different component of bile involved in digestion and absorption of fats.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hay's test is critical for detecting bile salts in urine, particularly when evaluating patients for liver dysfunction that impacts bile pigment excretion.
  • This test's ability to demonstrate the presence of bile salts through the simple mechanism of altering urine surface tension is a crucial diagnostic tool in assessing liver function.

questions.text: All of the following are examples of Dermal melanocytosis Ceruloderma except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Becker's nevus

 

  • Becker's nevus is the correct answer as it is not an example of dermal melanocytosis Ceruloderma.
  • Becker's nevus is a type of hamartoma, which typically appears as a unilateral, hyperpigmented patch that often develops hair (hypertrichosis).
  • It usually occurs on the upper trunk, shoulder, or arm and is more commonly observed in males.
  • It does not involve the dermal melanocytes as seen in conditions classified under dermal melanocytosis Ceruloderma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nevus of Ito and Option B. Nevus of Ota: Are both forms of dermal melanocytosis, where melanocytes are entrapped in the dermis during development. These conditions typically present with bluish or grayish pigmentation on the skin and are found in areas innervated by the first two branches of the trigeminal nerve (Nevus of Ota) or in the shoulder area (Nevus of Ito).

 

Option C. Mongolian spots: Are a type of dermal melanocytosis commonly seen in infants, especially those of East Asian, Native American, or African descent. These spots are characterized by bluish-gray pigmentation, typically on the sacral area, and usually fade during childhood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Becker's nevus is not classified as a form of dermal melanocytosis Ceruloderma but rather as a hamartoma involving epidermal and connective tissue elements.
  • This distinction is important for accurate diagnosis and understanding of the condition’s etiology and management.

questions.text:
Match the following descriptions of paraphilic disorders with their respective terms:

 

Descriptions:

 

  1. A 35-year-old man derived sexual excitement and gratification from making obscene telephone calls to unknown women.
  2. A 28-year-old woman reported to the emergency department explaining that she experiences sexual arousal from the administration of enemas, which she performs on herself regularly.
  3. A 40-year-old man, during his psychiatric evaluation, expressed that he obtains sexual pleasure from the sight of feces.
  4. A 42-year-old man is being assessed for episodes during which he uses obscene language to obtain sexual excitement in public places.

 

Terms:

 

A. Caprolalia

B. Scatalogia

C. Coprophilia

D. Klismaphilia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

  • Caprolalia involves obtaining sexual excitement through the use of obscene language.
  • Scatalogia is associated with making obscene telephone calls, often to strangers.
  • Coprophilia refers to sexual gratification derived from the sight or interaction with feces.
  • Klismaphilia involves sexual arousal from the administration of enemas.


Educational Objective:

 

Some additional terminologies -

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with hearing loss and occasional ear discharge. Otoscopic examination shows retraction of the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. Based on the staging of the retraction of pars flaccida shown in the image, what is the likely stage of this patient if the examination reveals a deep retraction pocket with adherent malleus, but without ossicular erosion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

  • The stages of pars flaccida retraction are classified based on the extent of retraction and involvement of ossicular chain:
  • Type 0 (Normal): The pars flaccida is not retracted and appears normal.
  • Type I: There is a slight retraction of the pars flaccida without touching the ossicles.
  • Type II: The retraction pocket touches the neck of the malleus but does not affect other ossicles or their function.
  • Type III: The retraction pocket is deeper, involves adhesion of the pars flaccida to the malleus, potentially leading to malleus fixation, but without erosion of the ossicles.
  • Type IV: The retraction is severe with erosion of the ossicular chain, which may lead to more significant hearing loss and other complications.
  • In the scenario described, since the retraction pocket is deep and the malleus is adherent but not eroded, it corresponds to Type III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Type III pars flaccida retraction as characterized by a deep retraction pocket with malleus adhesion but no ossicular erosion.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female patient visits a healthcare center in Delhi with complaints of recurrent urinary tract infections. The microbiology lab receives a urine sample for analysis. To determine the specific characteristics of the bacterial strain involved, the laboratory technician decides to use Craigie's tube method. Given this information, what does Craigie’s tube method differentiate between?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Motile and nonmotile strains

 

  • Craigie’s tube method is a technique used to determine the motility of bacterial strains.
  • It involves inoculating a semi-solid medium with the bacteria and observing their ability to move away from the line of inoculation.
  • Bacteria that can move will diffuse out into the medium, creating a cloudiness or a diffuse line, indicating motility.
  • Those that remain localized along the line of inoculation are non-motile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virulent and avirulent strains: Incorrect because Craigie's tube method does not provide information regarding the virulence of bacterial strains.

 

Option C. Capsulated and noncapsulated strains: Incorrect as this method is not designed to differentiate between capsulated and non-capsulated bacteria.

 

Option D. Rough and smooth strains: Incorrect because it does not assess the surface characteristics (rough or smooth) of bacterial colonies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Craigie’s tube method is specifically utilized to distinguish between motile and nonmotile bacterial strains.
  • This differentiation is crucial in the identification and characterization of pathogens in clinical microbiology, aiding in the diagnosis and treatment of infections.

choices.text: Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct.
Statements 1 and 4 are correct.
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct.
All are correct.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

 

  • Statement 1: Risk of relapse of bipolar disorder is higher in postpartum period compared to pregnancy.
  • Statement 2: Lithium is the most teratogenic mood stabilizer.
  • Statement 3: Valproate use in pregnancy is associated with Ebstein’s anomaly in the baby.
  • Statement 4: Antipsychotics are less teratogenic and more effective for management of bipolar disorder in pregnancy.

 

Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Statements 1 and 4 are correct.

 

Statement 1. Risk of relapse of bipolar disorder is higher in the postpartum period compared to pregnancy This is correct. The postpartum period is a particularly vulnerable time for women with bipolar disorder, with a significant risk of relapse due to hormonal shifts, sleep deprivation, and psychosocial stressors.

 

Statement 4. Antipsychotics are less teratogenic and more effective for management of bipolar disorder in pregnancy: This is correct. Antipsychotics are generally considered less teratogenic than classic mood stabilizers and are often used as a safer alternative for managing bipolar disorder during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2. Lithium is the most teratogenic mood stabilizer: This statement is incorrect. While lithium has been associated with an increased risk of congenital malformations, particularly Ebstein’s anomaly, it is not considered the most teratogenic among mood stabilizers. Valproate is considered most teratogenic and is strongly associated with a higher risk of neural tube defects.

 

Statement 3. Valproate use in pregnancy is associated with Ebstein’s anomaly in the baby: This is incorrect. Valproate use during pregnancy is actually associated with neural tube defects (such as spina bifida), facial clefts, and cognitive impairment in the baby, not Ebstein’s anomaly, which is linked to lithium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden, severe chest pain radiating to his back. The pain is described as tearing in nature. His blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. A CT scan is performed and the image is provided below. Given the clinical history and radiographic findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic aortic aneurysm

 

  • The CT scan provided clearly shows a significant dilation of the ascending aorta, indicative of a thoracic aortic aneurysm.
  • This diagnosis is consistent with the patient's clinical presentation of sudden, severe, and tearing chest pain radiating to the back.
  • The combination of his risk factors, such as hypertension and smoking, further supports the likelihood of a thoracic aortic aneurysm.
  • This condition results from weakening of the aorta's wall, which can dilate or rupture under pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute myocardial infarction: While chest pain is a common symptom, the CT scan would not typically show changes in the aorta and the pain description and radiating nature are more typical of aortic involvement rather than coronary artery disease.

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism: Generally, presents with acute shortness of breath, chest pain that may be pleuritic, and often hypoxia. A CT scan might show a filling defect in the pulmonary arteries, not aortic dilation.

 

Option D. Esophageal rupture: This condition would present with severe chest pain, potentially with signs of mediastinal air on imaging due to escaped air from the esophagus into the chest cavity. The scan shows dilation specific to the aorta, not features typical of esophageal rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient present with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, particularly with risk factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking, a thoracic aortic aneurysm should be highly suspected.
  • CT imaging showing aortic dilation is critical for diagnosis and immediate management to prevent catastrophic outcomes like aortic rupture.

questions.text: A middle aged man presented to the emergency department with chest pain. His angiogram revealed active bleeding from a vein that runs alongside the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Which vein is most likely affected ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Great cardiac vein

 

  • The great cardiac vein primarily accompanies the left anterior descending artery along the anterior interventricular groove and collects blood from the front of the heart, making it the most likely vein to be involved in a bleeding event associated with the LAD.
  • The vein's close anatomical relationship with the LAD increases its vulnerability to trauma or rupture in cases of vascular or cardiac interventions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle cardiac vein: This vein runs along the posterior interventricular groove and typically accompanies the posterior descending artery, not the LAD, making it less likely to be the site of bleeding in this scenario.

 

Option B. Small cardiac vein: It usually runs along the right margin of the heart, accompanying the right coronary artery, and would not be involved in bleeding associated with the LAD.

 

Option D. Anterior cardiac vein: Drains the anterior right ventricular wall and directly enters the right atrium, generally not associated with the LAD or its complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the anatomical course of the great cardiac vein in relation to the left anterior descending artery is crucial for diagnosing vascular injuries in this area.
  • This knowledge is vital during interventions involving the LAD, where inadvertent damage to the great cardiac vein can result in significant complications.

questions.text:
Match each device listed in Column A with the maximum FiO2 it delivers, as shown in Column B. 

 

Column A:

 

1. High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)

2. Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)

3. Hudson Mask

4. Nasal Cannula at 3 L/min Oxygen Flow

 

Column B:

 

a. 30-35% Fio2

b. 90% -100 % FiO2

c. Up to 80% FiO2

d. 40-60% FiO2
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b 2-c 3-d 4-a

 

Explanation:

 

High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) can deliver up to 100 % FiO2 depending on the device settings and patient's inspiratory flow rate, offering a high level of oxygen delivery and humidification.

 

Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM) provides up to 80% FiO2 when properly fitted and the reservoir bag is kept inflated, ensuring a high concentration of oxygen is available for the patient.

 

Hudson Mask, also known as a simple mask, can deliver FiO2 levels between 40-60% based on the oxygen flow rate.

 

Nasal Cannula at 3 L/min Oxygen Flow typically provides 32% FiO2, making it suitable for patients requiring low to moderate additional oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxygen delivery devices are an essential aspect of managing patients with respiratory distress or hypoxemia.

choices.text: History of tubal surgery

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of endometriosis and tubal surgery is considering in vitro fertilization and is also interested in using an intrauterine device for contraception. She is concerned about her risk for ectopic pregnancy. Which factor most significantly increases this patient's risk for an ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) History of tubal surgery

 

  • This is the most significant risk factor for ectopic pregnancy among the options listed.
  • Tubal surgery can cause scarring or other alterations to the fallopian tubes, increasing the likelihood of an embryo implanting there instead of the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In vitro fertilization: While associated with an increased risk, especially in women with existing tubal damage, it generally poses less risk than a history of tubal surgery.

 

Option B. Intrauterine device: If pregnancy occurs with an IUD, the risk of it being ectopic is higher, though overall risk of pregnancy is very low.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: May slightly increase the risk of an ectopic pregnancy due to pelvic adhesions, but less so than tubal surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For women with a history of tubal surgery, the risk of an ectopic pregnancy is notably higher, making it a critical factor to consider in pregnancy planning and contraception decisions.

questions.text:
Two social workers are evaluating the needs of families for a community support program in a suburban area. They assessed 60 families to decide if they require additional social services. The results are as follows:

 

  • Both social workers agreed that 22 families require additional services.
  • Both agreed that 28 families do not require additional services.
  • Social worker A assessed that 35 families require services and 25 do not.
  • Social worker B assessed that 40 families require services and 20 do not.

 

Calculate the Kappa statistic to determine the level of agreement between the two social workers regarding the need for additional services for these families.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 0.66

 

To solve this:

 

1. Observed Agreement (Po):

 

Total agreements = Agreed 'Yes' + Agreed 'No' = 22 (Yes) + 28 (No) = 50 agreements

 𝑃𝑜=50/60 = 0.833

 

2. Expected Agreement (Pe):

  • Probability A says Yes = 35/60
  • Probability A says No = 25/60
  • Probability B says Yes = 40/60
  • Probability B says No = 20/60

 

Expected probability both say Yes = Probability A says Yes * Probability B says Yes

 

Expected probability both say No = Probability A says No * Probability B says No

 

 

Pe = (0.58 x 0.66) + (0.42 x 0.33) = 0.52

 

3. Kappa (κ) calculation:

 

 

Kappa (κ) = (0.83 – 0.52)/ (1- 0.52) = 0.66

 

Thus, the Kappa statistic is about 0.65, indicating substantial agreement between the two social workers beyond what would be expected by chance alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kappa Interpretation:
    • 0 = agreement equivalent to chance.
    • 0 – 0.20 = slight agreement.
    • 0.21 – 0.40 = fair agreement.
    • 0.41 – 0.60 = moderate agreement.
    • 0.61 – 0.80 = substantial agreement.
    • 0.81 – 0.99 = near perfect agreement
    • 1 = perfect agreement.

questions.text: Which cytogenetic technique would be most appropriate for revealing the terminal regions of chromosomes to identify any potential telomeric abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) T-banding

 

  • T-banding is a cytogenetic technique specifically used to stain the telomeric regions of chromosomes.
  • This method is particularly useful for identifying structural abnormalities in the terminal regions of the chromosomes, which can be crucial for diagnosing certain genetic disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: Involves using a Giemsa stain to reveal a series of bands along all chromosomes. It is the most common technique used for karyotyping but does not specifically highlight telomeric regions as effectively as T-banding.

 

Option B. C-banding: Focuses on staining the centromeric regions of chromosomes with silver salts, which contain constitutive heterochromatin, and is used to identify variations in these specific areas.

 

Option D. Q-banding: This is similar to G-banding in that it uses quinacrine mustard which fluoresces under UV light, showing patterns similar to G-banding. Like G-banding, it does not specialize in telomeric regions.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • For detailed analysis of the terminal regions of chromosomes, particularly to detect abnormalities in telomeres, T-banding is the most suitable cytogenetic technique.
  • This specificity helps in diagnosing genetic conditions related to telomeric structure and function.

questions.text: You as an intern, are accompanying your Dermatology senior resident for reference of a 2-week-old neonate in paediatric ward with the following skin finding. You diagnose it as a disorder of Eccrine glands, which the Senior Resident in derma also accepts. At what level does the obstruction occur in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stratum corneum

 

  • The image you provided appears to show a newborn with what is commonly referred to as "miliaria crystallina," a skin condition involving the sweat glands, specifically the eccrine glands.
  • This condition is characterized by the appearance of tiny, clear blisters resulting from sweat trapped under the skin, typically occurring in hot and humid conditions.
  • In miliaria crystallina, the obstruction occurs in the sweat ducts at the level of the stratum corneum, the outermost layer of the skin.
  • This layer becomes obstructed, leading to the trapping of sweat just beneath it, which forms the visible vesicles or blisters on the skin surface without inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malpighian layer: Also known as the stratum basale and stratum spinosum, this is deeper in the epidermis and is not the site of obstruction in miliaria crystallina.

 

Option C. Dermoepidermal junction: This is the junction between the dermis and epidermis and is not involved in the pathology of miliaria crystallina.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as the correct answer is specifically the stratum corneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Miliaria crystallina is a disorder resulting from the obstruction of eccrine sweat ducts at the level of the stratum corneum.
  • Recognizing the characteristic clear vesicles can help diagnose the condition and manage it appropriately, typically by reducing heat exposure and improving skin ventilation to resolve the symptoms.

questions.text: During a labor and delivery training session, medical students are learning about tools for fetal monitoring. An instructor shows an image of a device used to directly monitor fetal heart rate during labor. Identify the device?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal scalp electrode

 

This device is used to provide a continuous and direct measure of the fetal heart rate by being attached to the fetal scalp.

 

  • They are used in internal electronic fetal monitoring during labor
  • Intrauterine pressure can also be measured simultaneously by passing a catheter in the uterine cavity
  • Internal monitoring can be done only when the cervix is at least 3-4 cm dilated and the membranes have ruptured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal ECG probe: While similar in function, this is more commonly used to refer to external devices, not those attached directly to the fetal scalp.

 

Option B. CTG (Cardiotocography): Refers to the monitoring system that records the fetal heartbeat and the uterine contractions during pregnancy. CTG is a broader term that typically includes both external and internal devices such as the fetal scalp electrode.

 

Option D. Fetal scalp blood sampler: Used to obtain a small blood sample from the fetal scalp to check for oxygen levels and other metabolic conditions but does not continuously monitor fetal heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal scalp electrodes are essential in providing accurate, real-time data on fetal heart rate during labor, especially in scenarios where external monitors fail to capture clear, consistent readings.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta is managing a community health initiative to evaluate renal function in a rural district in India. As part of this initiative, GFR was measured in a group of 100 individuals. The average GFR recorded was 85 ml/min, with a standard deviation of 25 ml/min. To assess the reliability of these measurements and provide data for policymaking, Dr. Mehta decides to calculate the 90% confidence interval for the mean GFR. What is this interval?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) 81-89 ml/min

 

The 90% confidence interval (CI) for the mean is calculated using the formula:

 

Educational Objective:

 

Confidence intervals

 

  • A confidence interval gives an estimated range of values which is likely to include an unknown population parameter, the estimated range being calculated from a given set of sample data
  • Confidence Intervals (CI) = Mean ± Z (Standard error), where ‘Z’ is the Critical value for the given CI, and SE = SD/√n (SD Standard deviatio n, n = Sample size)
  1. Critical value for 90% Confidence level (Z68) = 1.0
  2. Critical value for 90% Confidence level (Z90) = 1.645
  3. Critical value for 95% Confidence level (Z95) = 1.96
  4. Critical value for 98% Confidence level (Z98) = 2.33
  5. Critical value for 99% Confidence level (Z99) = 2.575

choices.text: Suicide rate in this condition is less than 1%.
Most individuals with this condition seek treatment within the first year of symptoms appearing.
The lifetime prevalence of this disorder is higher in women than in men.
It is most prevalent among individuals in their late 50s and early 60s.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents complaining of persistent sadness, decreased energy, and loss of interest in activities he once enjoyed. These symptoms have been present for more than six weeks. He reports difficulty concentrating at work and disrupted sleep patterns. Given the duration and nature of his symptoms, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The lifetime prevalence of this disorder is higher in women than in men.

 

  • The description provided suggests that the man is experiencing symptoms consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD).
  • The statement that the lifetime prevalence of this disorder is higher in women than in men is accurate and supported by epidemiological data.
  • Women are nearly twice as likely as men to be diagnosed with depression over their lifetime. This difference is attributed to various biological, hormonal, and social factors that affect women differently than men.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicide rate in this condition is less than 1%: This statement is not true. Suicide rates in those suffering from depression ranges from 10-15%.

 

Option B. Most individuals with this condition seek treatment within the first year of symptoms appearing: Unfortunately, many individuals with depression do not seek treatment quickly due to stigma, lack of awareness, or other barriers.

 

Option D. It is most prevalent among individuals in their late 50s and early 60s: Depression can affect individuals of any age, but it is not most prevalent in this age group. Prevalence rates can vary, but there is a significant incidence in younger adults as well as older adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidemiology of major depressive disorder:
    • According to National Mental Health Study (NMHS-2016), carried out by NIMHANS, depression is the most common mental illness in India (excluding tobacco use disorders)
    • Most common age of onset is middle-age, and the mean age of onset is 40 years, prevalence is increasing in young people too.
    • Female: Male prevalence = 2:1
    • More common in separated, divorced or widowed than married individuals.
    • Amongst psychiatric disorders, depression is associated with maximum DALYs (disability-adjusted life years)
    • Depression is the most common cause of suicide.
    • Suicide rate in depression - 10-15%

questions.text: During a prenatal class at a community health center, an obstetrician explains the stages of labor to medical students. The discussion focuses on the mechanisms of labor, particularly how the fetal head moves through the birth canal. The obstetrician emphasizes the importance of specific fetal head movements necessary for a safe and successful delivery. Which movement of the fetal head is essential as a prerequisite for its descent during labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion

 

  • Flexion of the fetal head is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter (suboccipitobregmatic diameter) of the head to present to the birth canal, facilitating easier descent.
  • This position reduces the presenting diameter and aligns the fetal head optimally for passing through the mother's pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Internal rotation: Although internal rotation is important, it occurs as the head descends through the pelvis to align with the pelvic outlet but is not a prerequisite for the initial descent.

 

Option C. Extension: Extension of the fetal head occurs later in the delivery process, specifically during the actual birth of the head, allowing it to navigate under the pubic symphysis.

 

Option D. Restitution: Restitution refers to the rotation of the fetal head after the head has been delivered, aligning it with the shoulders, which are still aligned in the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flexion of the fetal head is a critical initial movement in labor, allowing the head to engage in the pelvis in the most favorable position for descent, which is key to progressing through the stages of labor effectively.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma is reviewing the results of a recently concluded randomized trial conducted in Telangana, comparing the efficacy of two antihypertensive drugs. Although the trial results indicated a statistically significant difference in efficacy between the two drugs with a p-value of <0.005, subsequent studies and a meta-analysis have confirmed that there is no actual difference in efficacy between them. This scenario is an example of which type of statistical error?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I error (alpha error)

 

  • A Type I error, also known as an alpha error, occurs when the null hypothesis (that there is no difference between groups) is incorrectly rejected.
  • In this scenario, the p-value of <0.005 suggested a significant difference when in fact no true difference exists, leading to a false positive result. T
  • his error reflects a false claim of an effect (e.g., claiming that one drug is more effective than another when they are actually the same), which aligns with the scenario described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type II error (beta error): This occurs when the null hypothesis is incorrectly accepted when it should have been rejected, leading to a false negative result. This is not the case here, as the study incorrectly found a difference.

 

Option C. 1 – alpha: This represents the confidence level, essentially the probability of correctly not rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true (i.e., making a correct decision when there is no effect). This is not directly relevant to the error described.

 

Option D. 1 – beta: This represents the power of the study, which is the probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false (i.e., detecting an effect when there is one). Again, this is not the error that occurred.

 

Educational objective:

 

A test with a high specificity has a low Type I error rate

 

  • False positive rate (a) = 1 – specificity
  • False negative rate (b) = 1 – sensitivity

choices.text: Superior layer of coronary ligament
Hepatoduodenal portion of lesser omentum

questions.text: Which structure should be incised to safely access the omental bursa while protecting the structures entering the porta hepatitis and the blood vessels supplying the stomach?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatoduodenal portion of lesser omentum

 

  • This is the optimal choice for incision when needing access to the omental bursa during abdominal surgeries.
  • It strategically avoids the portal triad and other vital structures, providing a direct route to the omental bursa without compromising the vascular or structural integrity of the liver or stomach.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior layer of coronary ligament: This ligament secures the liver to the diaphragm and does not provide direct or safe access to the omental bursa.

 

Option C. Gastrohepatic ligament: Part of the lesser omentum, but less ideal than the hepatoduodenal portion because it has significant vascular structures that may be at risk during incision.

 

Option D. Gastrosplenic ligament: This ligament connects the stomach to the spleen and is not relevant for accessing the omental bursa; incising it could risk injury to the stomach and spleen vasculature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selecting the hepatoduodenal portion of the lesser omentum for incision during surgical approaches to the omental bursa is critical for avoiding damage to key vascular and structural components in the upper abdomen.
  • This choice is crucial for successful surgical outcomes and patient safety during complex abdominal procedures.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, G4, is in active labor at 37 weeks’ gestation. During labor management, the obstetrician performs an amniotomy to accelerate labor when the cervix is dilated to 5 cm. Upon rupture of the membranes, the amniotic fluid appears to be a golden color. What is the most likely cause of the golden coloration of the amniotic fluid observed after amniotomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rh isoimmunization

 

  • This condition occurs when a Rh-negative mother develops antibodies against Rh-positive fetal blood cells.
  • The antibodies can cross the placenta and break down fetal red blood cells, leading to hemolysis, which results in the production of bilirubin.
  • Elevated bilirubin levels can give the amniotic fluid a golden or yellowish color, known as "golden" or "yellow" amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal distress: Typically leads to meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which is greenish, not golden.

 

Option C. Post maturity: Associated with meconium-stained fluid due to fetal stress in overdue pregnancies, but the color tends to be greenish or dark, not golden.

 

Option D. Fetal demise: Can lead to changes in the color of the amniotic fluid, usually becoming darker or murkier, but not typically golden.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rh isoimmunization is a serious condition that can cause fetal anemia, jaundice, and even hydrops fetalis, reflected in the altered color of the amniotic fluid.
  • It underscores the importance of Rh factor compatibility testing and appropriate management throughout pregnancy to prevent hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn.

questions.text: Dr. Kaur, a public health official from Uttarakhand, is analysing the relationship between infant mortality rate (IMR) and economic status across various districts. The data includes IMR and economic indicators such as income levels and employment rates. She hypothesizes that as economic status improves, IMR should decrease. Which of the following correlation coefficients would most likely represent the relationship between IMR and economic status in her study?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) r = –0.8

 

  • The coefficient of correlation (r) quantifies the degree to which two variables are related.
  • Coefficients close to +1 or -1 indicate a strong relationship, with the sign indicating the direction (positive or negative). In the context of IMR and economic status:
  • A negative correlation coefficient (like r = -0.8) suggests that as economic status improves (increases), IMR decreases, which is consistent with typical public health findings where higher economic status correlates with better health outcomes.
  • This strong negative correlation (close to -1) indicates a robust inverse relationship.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. r = +1: This would indicate a perfect positive correlation, meaning as economic status increases, IMR would also increase, which is contrary to usual public health observations.

 

Option B. r = –1: This would indicate a perfect negative correlation, meaning as economic status increases, IMR decreases perfectly. While conceptually correct in direction, it is highly unlikely in real-world data to observe a perfect correlation.

 

Option C. r = +0.22: This indicates a weak positive correlation, suggesting that as economic status increases, IMR slightly increases, which again does not align with typical findings in public health studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A correlation coefficient closes to -1 indicates a strong inverse relationship, essential for public health planning and interventions to improve health equity.

questions.text: A neurology resident is taking seminar on neuromuscular anatomy with interns, focusing on muscles with dual nerve supplies. The session explores the implications of dual nerve supply in muscle function and surgical planning. Which of the following muscles is only supplied by a single nerve, lacking dual innervation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pronator Teres

 

  • The pronator teres muscle is primarily innervated by the median nerve alone.
  • It does not exhibit dual innervation like some other muscles, which means it has a single source of neural input.
  • This characteristic is particularly relevant when considering potential impacts of nerve injury or during surgical interventions where nerve preservation is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexor Digitorum Profundus: FDP for medial ½ is innervated by the ulnar nerve and FDP lateral ½ is innervated by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve

 

Option B. Pectoralis Major - It is innervated by both the medial and lateral pectoral nerves. The dual nerve supply ensures robust muscle activation and is important in surgeries involving the chest to prevent unintended weakness.

 

Option C. Subscapularis: Although primarily innervated by the upper and lower subscapular nerves (both branches of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus), it is considered to have dual innervation due to the separate contributions of these two nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pronator teres muscle’s singular innervation by the median nerve is critical for its function in forearm pronation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, who has just given birth to her second child, consults with her obstetrician during a postpartum visit. She is breastfeeding and seeks advice on suitable contraception methods that are safe during lactation and will not affect her milk supply. What is the most appropriate contraceptive method for this breastfeeding postpartum patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Progestin-only contraceptives

 

  • These are highly recommended for breastfeeding mothers because they do not contain estrogen, which can interfere with milk production.
  • Progestin-only pills, injections, or implants provide effective contraception without significantly affecting breast milk supply.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Combined oral contraceptives: Not typically recommended during lactation, especially in the early postpartum period, as they contain estrogen, which may reduce breast milk production and could potentially affect the infant.

 

Option C. Barrier methods: While safe during breastfeeding, barrier methods like condoms or diaphragms are generally less reliable than hormonal contraceptives and might not offer the most convenient or preferred option for many women.

 

Option D. Withdrawal method: This method is less effective at preventing pregnancy compared to other contraceptive methods and provides no protection against sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For breastfeeding mothers seeking effective and safe postpartum contraception, progestin-only contraceptives are an excellent choice.
  • They provide reliable contraception without compromising breast milk production or the health of the infant.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding high-quality CPR for adults?

 

  1. Push hard (5-6cm depth)
  2. Push fast (100-120/min frequency)
  3. Allow for complete chest recoil
  4. Minimize interruptions in compressions ≤20 seconds
  5. Rotate compressor every 5 min. or earlier if fatigued
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

  • High-quality CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) for adults involves several key components that are essential for improving the likelihood of survival and outcomes after cardiac arrest.
  • These components include:
  1. Adequate Compression Depth: Compressions should be at least 5 cm (2 inches) deep but not more than 6 cm (2.4 inches).
  2. Proper Compression Rate: The rate of compressions should be between 100 and 120 compressions per minute.
  3. Allow Complete Chest Recoil: It's crucial to let the chest return to its normal position completely after each compression to allow the heart to refill with blood.
  4. Minimize Interruptions: Interruptions in chest compressions should be kept to less than 10 seconds to maximize blood flow during CPR.
  5. Avoid Excessive Ventilation: Over-ventilation can be harmful. It is recommended to avoid excessive ventilation to prevent increasing intrathoracic pressure and reducing venous return to the heart.
  6. Rotation of Compressors: To prevent fatigue and maintain the quality of compressions, it is recommended to rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or sooner if the compressor is tired.
  7. Compression-Ventilation Ratio: If no advanced airway is in place, a compression-to-ventilation ratio of 30:2 should be used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High-quality CPR for adults requires all the specified techniques to ensure optimal outcomes.
  • Compressing at a depth of 5-6 cm and a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute, allowing for complete chest recoil, minimizing interruptions in compressions to under 10 seconds, and avoiding excessive ventilation are all recommended practices to maximize the effectiveness of cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

choices.text: It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum
It is where the presenting part can be palpated
It appears slightly more pink than the upper segment
It is just below the round ligaments

questions.text: A first-year obstetrics resident is performing her first cesarean section. The supervising surgeon is instructing her on identifying the lower uterine segment, crucial for making the surgical incision. What is the most reliable method for a first-year resident to identify the lower uterine segment during a cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum

 

  • This is the most accurate guideline for identifying the lower uterine segment during a cesarean section.
  • The uterovesical fold of peritoneum is a reflection of the peritoneum between the bladder and the uterus.
  • The lower uterine segment is located just beneath this fold and is the ideal site for the cesarean incision to minimize bleeding and facilitate easier access to the amniotic sac.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is where the presenting part can be palpated: This method can be misleading as the presenting part can sometimes be engaged in the upper segment or be in an abnormal position.

 

Option C. It appears slightly more pink than the upper segment: Color differences are not a reliable indicator for surgical landmarks due to variability in individual anatomy and changes during pregnancy.

 

Option D. It is just below the round ligaments: The round ligaments are not reliable landmarks for the lower uterine segment as they are located at the lateral edges of the uterus and do not provide a clear indication of the segmental division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lower uterine segment is best identified by locating the uterovesical peritoneal fold during a cesarean section.
  • Understanding and recognizing this anatomical feature are crucial for surgical accuracy and safety, reducing the risk of complications during the procedure.

questions.text:
Dr. Chandra, a senior policy advisor in the Health Ministry, is refining national biodefense strategies. She evaluates pathogens based on their classification into different categories of bioterrorism threats.

 

Which of the following pathogens would Dr. Chandra prioritize for immediate preparedness measures due to its classification as a Category A bioterrorism threat?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smallpox

 

  • Smallpox is classified as a Category A bioterrorism threat due to its high potential to cause mass casualties and significant public panic.
  • It requires a substantial healthcare infrastructure to manage, including vaccination programs and isolation units, given its high mortality rate and potential for widespread dissemination.
  • The eradication of smallpox and the availability of existing vaccines do not diminish its potential threat if used as a bioweapon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin toxin: While dangerous, ricin toxin falls under Category B. It can cause significant morbidity and is moderately easy to disseminate, but does not generally lead to mass casualties like smallpox.

 

Option C. Q fever: Also a Category B threat, Q fever requires enhanced diagnostic capacity due to its moderate morbidity and relatively low mortality. It doesn’t invoke the widespread panic or require the extensive healthcare response associated with Category A agents.

 

Option D. Glanders: Glanders is another Category B threat, known for its moderate morbidity and low mortality, and like Q fever and ricin toxin, it lacks the mass casualty potential of smallpox.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 24-year-old male underwent ACL (anterior cruciate ligament) reconstruction surgery in the lithotomy position, with support at the popliteal fossae and proximal tibiae but not at the ankles. The day after surgery, he reported reduced sensation on the lateral side of his right leg and foot and had difficulty dorsiflexing his right foot. Given the postoperative symptoms of decreased lateral leg and foot sensation and dorsiflexion difficulty, which muscle innervated by the implicated nerve is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor Digitorum Longus

 

  • This muscle is innervated by the peroneal nerve, which is susceptible to compression when the knee's lateral area is unsupported in surgery.
  • The peroneal nerve's impairment would lead to the reported symptoms, specifically affecting dorsiflexion and lateral foot sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexor Hallucis Longus: Innervated by the tibial nerve, not typically associated with the described symptoms.

 

Option B. Abductor Hallucis: Also innervated by the tibial nerve and medial plantar nerve unrelated to dorsiflexion or lateral sensory changes.

 

Option D. Semi-Membranosus: Innervated by tibial portion of the sciatic nerve; involvement would not result in the specific symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The peroneal nerve, vulnerable to pressure near the fibular head during certain surgical positions, is crucial for foot dorsiflexion and lateral leg sensation.
  • Its damage can lead to significant functional impairments, underscoring the importance of proper limb positioning during surgery to prevent such issues.

questions.text: During a reproductive biology seminar, a lecturer discusses the process of fertilization and the critical role of zona pellucida proteins in the regulation of sperm entry into the oocyte. One particular focus is on the zona hardening event that prevents polyspermy after the first sperm penetrates the oocyte. Which zona pellucida protein is primarily responsible for zona hardening after sperm penetration, thus preventing further sperm from entering the oocyte?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ZP2

 

  • ZP2 is the zona pellucida protein largely responsible for zona hardening after sperm penetration.
  • This process is crucial for preventing polyspermy, ensuring that only one sperm can fertilize the oocyte.
  • Post-fertilization, modifications in ZP2 prevent additional sperm from binding to the zona pellucida, thereby ensuring the integrity and viability of the fertilized egg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ZP1 and Option C. ZP3: Are important for initial sperm binding and activation but do not play the primary role in zona hardening post-fertilization.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as ZP2, listed among the options, is indeed responsible for this function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The role of ZP2 in zona hardening is crucial for insights into fertilization and the prevention of polyspermy.
  • This knowledge is essential in the field of reproductive biology and can inform techniques used in assisted reproductive technology (ART).

questions.text: A forensic expert is called to examine skeletal remains found in an abandoned warehouse. The remains are largely intact, and determining the age of the individual is crucial for the ongoing investigation. The expert notes a key feature in the sternum to assist with age estimation. According to the observed rule, if the body of the sternum is longer and more than twice the length of the manubrium, the individual was likely an adult. Which rule is the forensic expert applying to assess the age of the skeletal remains?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyrtl's rule

 

  • Hyrtl’s rule states that the manubrium of the female sternum exceeds half the length of the body, while the body in the male sternum is, at least, twice as long as the manubrium.
  • This anthropometric measurement can help in identifying skeletal remains.

 

Male - 46.2

 

Female - 54.3

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puppe's rule: pertains to the sequence of overlapping bullet holes, relevant in forensic ballistics rather than skeletal analysis.

 

Option B. Ashley's rule: Is a method used in forensic anthropology to help estimate sex from the sternum (skeletal remains)

 

Option D. Young's rule: It is applied in pediatric pharmacology to calculate medication dosage based on age and is not used in skeletal analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to Hyrtl’s law, manubrio corpus index or sternal index exceeds 50 in females and is less than 50 in males or the body is longer and more than the twice the length of the manubrium in males

choices.text: Elevation in the levels of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG)
Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH

questions.text: In a clinical seminar on reproductive endocrinology, the discussion focuses on the biochemical profiles characteristic of Stein-Leventhal syndrome, known as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). A specialist outlines the typical hormonal imbalances and metabolic disruptions associated with the condition. Which of the following biochemical findings is NOT typical of Stein-Leventhal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevation in the levels of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG)

 

  • This option is incorrect as SHBG levels are typically decreased in Stein-Leventhal syndrome, not elevated.
  • Lower levels of SHBG in PCOS are due to the hyperinsulinemia associated with insulin resistance, which inhibits SHBG production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH: This is a characteristic finding in PCOS, where the LH to FSH ratio is often elevated, contributing to the pathophysiology of the syndrome.

 

Option C. Insulin resistance: A common feature in PCOS, insulin resistance contributes to many of the metabolic complications associated with the syndrome, including type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular risks.

 

Option D. Elevation of plasma testosterone: Women with PCOS typically have higher levels of circulating androgens, including testosterone, which is responsible for many of the syndrome's clinical features such as hirsutism, acne, and anovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of Stein-Leventhal syndrome, biochemical features include elevated LH relative to FSH, insulin resistance, and increased plasma testosterone levels.
  • Contrary to some disorders that increase SHBG, PCOS is associated with decreased SHBG levels, which affects the bioavailability of sex hormones and exacerbates symptoms.

choices.text: A4, B3, C1, D2
A1, B2, C4, D3

questions.text:
Match the following surgical instruments with the surgeries for which they are typically used:

 

Instruments:

 

 

Surgeries:

 

​​​​​​​
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A4, B3, C1, D2

 

Explanation:

 

A4: Mollison Mastoid Retractor used during Mastoidectomy - This retractor is used to provide visibility and access during mastoid surgeries, correctly matching with 4) Mastoidectomy.

 

B3: Dennis Browne Tonsil Holding Forceps used during Tonsillectomy - These forceps are specialized for grasping and manipulating the tonsils during extraction, properly paired with 3) Tonsillectomy.

 

C1: Freer Elevator used during Septoplasty - The Freer Elevator is utilized to delicately separate mucosal tissues from the cartilage during nasal septum surgeries, aligning with 1) Septoplasty.

 

D2: Tracheal Dilator used during Tracheostomy - This dilator assists in opening the trachea to facilitate the insertion of a tracheostomy tube, matching with 2) Tracheostomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Learn to correctly identify and match the Mollison Mastoid Retractor with Mastoidectomy, Dennis Browne Tonsil Holding Forceps with Tonsillectomy, Freer Elevator with Septoplasty, and Tracheal Dilator with Tracheostomy.

choices.text: Antigenic drift in HCV envelope proteins
Immune complex formation with HCV envelope proteins
Poor B-cell response to HCV envelope proteins
Non-neutralizing nature of the antibodies against HCV envelope proteins

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to a tertiary care hospital in Pune for a routine health checkup due to his history of intravenous drug use. He appears well and reports no symptoms. Blood tests reveal abnormal liver enzyme levels, and subsequent testing confirms an active hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Despite the presence of high titers of IgG antibodies against the HCV envelope protein, his viral load remains high, indicating ongoing viral replication. What could be the most likely reason that these antibodies are unable to clear the virus from his system?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-neutralizing nature of the antibodies against HCV envelope proteins

 

  • The antibodies may be unable to neutralize the virus despite being present in high titers.
  • This could be due to the inability of the antibodies to bind to crucial epitopes on the envelope protein that are necessary to prevent the virus from infecting cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antigenic drift in HCV envelope proteins: While antigenic drift could affect the efficacy of antibodies by changing the viral epitopes, it does not directly explain the ineffectiveness of already existing antibodies.

 

Option B. Immune complex formation with HCV envelope proteins: The formation of immune complexes involves antigens and antibodies but typically leads to inflammation rather than a failure to clear the virus.

 

Option C. Poor B-cell response to HCV envelope proteins: A poor B-cell response would imply low levels of antibodies, which contradicts the scenario of high antibody titers being present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of high titers of IgG antibodies against Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) envelope proteins does not guarantee effective immunity, especially if these antibodies lack neutralizing capabilities.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with a history of irregular menstrual cycles and recurrent miscarriages is referred for to evaluate for potential congenital Müllerian anomalies. What is the preferred imaging modality for diagnosing congenital Müllerian anomalies?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance imaging

 

  • MRI is the preferred imaging modality when a congenital Müllerian anomaly is suspected.
  • It provides excellent soft tissue contrast and detailed images of the uterine anatomy, which are crucial for accurate diagnosis and classification of Müllerian anomalies.
  • MRI is non-invasive, does not use ionizing radiation, and offers superior delineation of the reproductive structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Computed Tomography (CT): While CT can provide detailed images, it is less preferable due to the use of ionizing radiation and its inferior soft tissue contrast compared to MRI.

 

Option C. Transabdominal sonography: Although useful for initial assessment, ultrasound may not provide as comprehensive detail as MRI, especially in complex anatomical anomalies.

 

Option D. Abdominopelvic x-ray series: This method uses ionizing radiation and offers significantly less detail about soft tissue structures, making it unsuitable for diagnosing Müllerian anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MRI is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosing congenital Müllerian anomalies due to its ability to provide detailed, high-resolution images of the uterine and adjacent pelvic anatomy without the risks associated with ionizing radiation.

questions.text: Based on the life cycle depicted, which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

  • Leptospirosis is correctly identified by the involvement of rodents as carriers and the spread of the organism through water contaminated by their urine.
  • Humans and other animals can become infected when they come into contact with this contaminated water, leading to the symptoms and transmission cycle as depicted in the diagram.
  • This disease's cycle is particularly unique due to its dependence on water bodies as a medium for transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hantavirus: This virus is typically spread through direct or indirect contact with rodent excreta but does not involve a water body in its transmission cycle.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Responsible for the plague, primarily transmitted via flea bites and direct contact with infected fluids or tissues, not through water bodies.

 

Option D. Rickettsia: A genus of bacteria transmitted primarily through tick bites, with no involvement of water bodies in its transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospirosis –

  • Leptospirosis results from a mild febrile illness to severe fatal disease with liver/kidney involvement.
  • Route of transmission is direct skin contact with infected rat’s urine
  • Occupational exposure at risk: Agricultural and lives tock farmers (rice fields, sugarcane fields, underground sewers, abattoir workers, meat/animal handlers, veterinarians)

questions.text: Dr. Varma, a public health officer, is tasked with improving the efficiency of healthcare services in a rural community clinic. As part of his efforts, he decides to implement a method to observe and record the activities of the healthcare staff at predetermined or random intervals to assess their work patterns and identify areas for improvement. Which of the following best describes the method he is using?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Work sampling

 

  • Work sampling is a method used to observe and record the activities of one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals.
  • This technique is particularly useful for analyzing work efficiency and determining how workers allocate their time among various activities, helping to identify inefficiencies and improve productivity in settings such as healthcare facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making: This refers to the process of making choices by identifying a decision, gathering information, and assessing alternative resolutions. It does not involve the observation and recording of activities.

 

Option B. Systems analysis: This involves studying an organization or business to identify its goals and purposes and creating systems and procedures that will achieve them in an efficient way. It is broader and more conceptual than the specific observation method described.

 

Option C. Network analysis: This is used for evaluating relationships within networks, including social networks, which does not pertain to the direct observation of individual tasks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Work Sampling: Systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals, carried out at pre-determined or random intervals.

 

It provides quantitative measurement of various activities.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the psychiatric clinic reporting a belief that different people he encounters throughout the day are actually the same individual who changes appearance. He describes feeling tracked and harassed by this person and exhibits significant distress while recounting his experiences. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fregoli Syndrome

 

  • Fregoli Syndrome is characterized by the delusional belief that different people the individual meets are in fact a single person who changes appearance or is in disguise.
  • This delusion typically includes a sense of persecution, where the patient feels that this person is tracking or harassing them, as described by the patient in this scenario.
  • This condition is a rare disorder and is considered a delusional misidentification syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Capgras Syndrome: This involves the belief that a friend, family member, or spouse has been replaced by an impostor. It is also a delusional misidentification syndrome but does not match the description of people being the same individual in disguise.

 

Option C. Othello Syndrome:  The patient has a false belief that the partner/spouse is having an affair.

 

Option D. Cotard Syndrome:  Here, patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delusional misidentification syndromes include Capgras syndrome, Fregoli’s syndrome, syndrome of intermetamorphosis and syndrome of subjective doubles.

 

 

Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 124-125.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice, pale stools, and hepatomegaly. The infant's bilirubin levels are predominantly conjugated. An ultrasound of the liver is performed and the image is given below. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biliary atresia

 

  • The ultrasound image shows the triangular cord sign, characterized by a hyperechoic density anterior to the portal vein, which is highly specific for biliary atresia.
  • This condition is a serious congenital disorder where the bile ducts inside or outside the liver are abnormally narrow, blocked, or absent.
  • The clinical symptoms of persistent jaundice, acholic stools (pale, clay-colored), and hepatomegaly align with this diagnosis, supporting the ultrasound findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neonatal hepatitis: This condition can also present with jaundice and hepatomegaly but typically does not show the triangular cord sign on ultrasound. Neonatal hepatitis usually affects the liver more diffusely and would not localize to the biliary tree as biliary atresia does.

 

Option B. Choledochal cyst: While this condition involves the bile ducts, it is characterized by cystic dilations of the bile duct rather than the fibrosis and duct obliteration seen in biliary atresia. Choledochal cysts would appear as cystic structures on ultrasound, not as a hyperechoic density.

 

Option D. Hepatic hemangioma: This is a benign tumor of the liver typically seen as a well-defined, hyperechoic lesion in the liver on ultrasound. It does not cause the triangular cord sign and is not associated with jaundice or acholic stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The triangular cord sign on ultrasound is highly indicative of biliary atresia in infants presenting with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, clay coloured stools, and hepatomegaly.
  • This finding is crucial for early diagnosis and management, as timely surgical intervention (Kasai procedure) can improve bile flow and liver function in affected infants.

questions.text: In a neuroanatomy session, medical students are discussing the venous structures related to the cavernous sinus using a cranial base illustration. The instructor focuses on understanding the venous drainage into the cavernous sinus. Based on the provided image, which vein does NOT drain into the pinned structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Petrosquamous sinus

 

  • The image provided shows a detailed anatomical illustration, likely of the base of the skull with a focus on the venous sinuses.
  • The structure highlighted with a blue pin is the cavernous sinus, which is a significant venous structure in the cranial cavity located on either side of the sella turcica.

 

The cavernous sinus receives blood from several veins, which include:

 

  • Superior ophthalmic vein (A): Drains blood from the orbit and is a significant tributary to the cavernous sinus.
  • Sphenoparietal sinus (C): Drains the sphenoid region and also contributes to the cavernous sinus.
  • Superficial middle cerebral vein (D): Often drains into the cavernous sinus or the sphenoparietal sinus and then to the cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

 

However:

 

  • Petrosquamous sinus is not typically listed as a tributary of the cavernous sinus. This sinus is less commonly referenced and does not directly communicate with the cavernous sinus, making it the correct answer for the structure that is not a tributary of the cavernous sinus in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drainage pattern into the cavernous sinus is crucial in the clinical context, especially for conditions involving venous circulation within the brain, such as thrombosis or spread of infections from facial veins to intracranial structures.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma is tasked with implementing a health education program to improve maternal health awareness in his district. He decides to use a model of health education that focuses on fostering a deep personal connection and belief in the health practices being promoted, to ensure that the community members not only understand but also internalize these health messages. Which model of health education is most appropriate for achieving 'internalization' of health education messages in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motivation model

 

  • The Motivation model of health education is focused on encouraging individuals to adopt new behaviors through internal motivation and understanding, which leads to 'internalization'.
  • This means that individuals adopt the health behaviors not just because they are told to do so, but because they believe in the importance and benefits of these behaviors for their own health and well-being.
  • This model is effective in community settings like the one Dr. Sharma is working in, where sustained behavioral change is crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medical model:  This model primarily focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of diseases rather than on education and prevention. It does not typically involve or promote the internalization of health behaviors.

 

Option B. Socio-environmental model:  This model emphasizes the impact of social and environmental factors on health. While it supports community-wide health improvements, it does not specifically target the internalization of behaviors at the individual level.

 

Option C. Service model:  This model involves the delivery of health services to improve public health but does not focus on educational aspects or on changing health behaviors through internalization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Motivation Model of Health education (Adoption Model)

 

  • Three stages in process of behavioural change:
    • Awareness: Interest
    • Motivation: Evaluation, Decision-making
    • Action: Adoption, Acceptance
  • Internalization: New idea/acquired behavior becomes part of own existing values

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with a history of seizures. Concerned about potential neurological involvement, the pediatrician orders a CT scan of the head and image is provided below. Based on the radiological findings and clinical presentation, which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the appearance on this child’s CT scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sturge-Weber syndrome

 

  • The CT scan image shows the characteristic "tram-track" calcifications on the cerebral cortex, which are indicative of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
  • These calcifications are typically cortical and occur parallel to the brain convolutions.
